key_points: The Suez Canal was blocked by the cargo ship 'The Ever Given' on 25th March 2021, affecting global trade.
The canal is a crucial link for trade between Asia and Europe, with around 12% of global trade passing through.
This incident could exacerbate the global economic impact given the ongoing effects of the Covid-19 pandemic.
Efforts to free the ship involved removing 27,000 cubic meters of sand.
Nigeria, being import-dependent, risks facing increased prices for goods due to delays in shipping.
Vice President and Head of Trade & Marine Operations at Gladius Commodities Limited, Okojie Larry, predicts price rises for various goods in Nigeria.
Larry anticipates the blockage could take days or weeks to clear, costing companies and leading to higher freight costs.
Private Oil Market Trader, Opeoluwa Dapo-Thomas, sees the impact on Nigeria as negligible but highlights increased costs for ship owners and insurance companies.
Despite the ship being partially refloated, normal traffic in the Suez Canal has yet to resume, affecting crude oil conveyance and causing potential demurrage and insurance claims.
Nigerian businesses are already incurring demurrages due to the blockage, with implications for market liquidity.
spokespersons: Okojie Larry (Vice President and Head of Trade & Marine Operations, Gladius Commodities Limited)
